statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: Dale Davis had 20 points and 14 rebounds, and Bonzi Wells scored 19 points to lead the Portland Trail Blazers to a 92-86 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics on Tuesday night.
article.headline: Blazers keep winning, rack up technicals
article.linkText: Tempers: Blazers stay 'hot' in beating Sonics
article.story:
SEATTLE (AP) -- The Portland Trail Blazers used Scottie Pippen's ejection as motivation in the second half. Dale Davis had 20 points and 14 rebounds, and Bonzi Wells scored 19 points to lead the Blazers to a 92-86 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics on Tuesday night. "I feel like the officials kind of let the game get out of hand," said Pippen, who had to leave the game in the final minute of the first half after receiving two technicals for arguing too vigorously because he thought he was fouled. "They had to use somebody as an example. Unfortunately, I was the example tonight." The Blazers won for the 10th time in 12 games and beat the Sonics for the eighth time in nine games, including two straight this season. Davis, who shot 9-for-10, said Pippen's ejection motivated the Blazers. "It was emotional, no doubt about it," he said. "Tempers flared and we felt like we were getting the short end of the stick. So the guys spoke their piece." Davis said the Blazers began to feel good in the second half. "It was a good thing because there was a lot of negative energy," he said. "I felt we did a good job of turning it into a positive." Blazers coach Maurice Cheeks agreed that Pippen's ejection was a key in his team's win. "When Scottie got thrown out, I think we all kind of pulled together," he said. Rasheed Wallace, who got his 13th technical of the season in the first half, kept his temper in the second half and finished with 16 points and 13 rebounds. The Sonics, who had won four of their previous five, got 27 points and six assists from Gary Payton. Seattle led by 16 points in the second quarter and were up by 10 at halftime. Seattle got 23 minutes from starting power forward Vin Baker, who played despite a badly bruised left shoulder that caused him to miss the Sonics' previous game. But Baker, who had 10 points and four rebounds, played only four minutes into the second half before coming out because he aggravated his left shoulder. Portland led 55-54 when Baker had to leave the game. Sonics coach Nate McMillan said Baker's departure was the difference. "We can't rely on a perimeter game to win and we didn't have that after Vin left," McMillan said. "Without Vin in the low post, we're limited and we can't rely on the jump shot." Desmond Mason said the Sonics lack an inside presence on offense without Baker. "It's always tough to play without Vin," Mason said. "He establishes a post game and the other teams have to double-team him." The Sonics led 79-77 after a driving layup by Payton with 3:53 to go before Wallace sank a 3-pointer from the left corner and Davis picked up a loose ball and made a layup. Payton responded with a 5-footer with 2:48 left to cut Portland's lead to 82-81 before Derek Anderson hit a 3-pointer for the Blazers. Desmond Mason's 19-footer with 1:56 left for Seattle cut the Blazers' lead to 85-83 before Wallace made a 5-footer and Anderson had a 16-footer to put the Blazers ahead 89-83 with 34.2 seconds remaining. The Blazers scored the first 11 points of the second half and Seattle didn't score in the third quarter until Mason's 12-footer with 4:48 gone. Wallace's 20-foot shot at the buzzer to end the third period cut the Sonics' lead to 69-68. Seattle was held to 15 points in the third quarter, when it shot 6-for-19. Seattle scored 10 unanswered points, with Brent Barry and Shammond Williams hitting 3-pointers, to take a 46-30 lead with 4:18 left in the first half before the Blazers went on a 12-0 run that included a 3-pointer by Pippen and a layup by Pippen. That cut the Sonics' lead to 46-42. But the Sonics took advantage of Pippen's two technicals whistled by referee Bennie Adams and one on Wallace that he got arguing Pippen's ejection to make three free throws and go ahead 54-44 at halftime.

Game notes
Pippen was ejected for the first time this season. ... The volatile Wallace had 41 technicals last season, leading the NBA in technicals for the second straight season. Wallace was ejected seven times last season, but he hasn't been this season. ... F Ruben Patterson, who signed as a free agent with the Blazers after spending two seasons in Seattle, had five points and two rebounds in 16 minutes. ... Payton needs two more points to pass James Worthy for 66th place on the NBA's career scoring list.
